conbody.p: Each course has its own folder. The introductory material follows a prescribed sequence, so the courses are labeled with the course number and title:

conbody.p:
Each course has a collection of subfolders:
topics: for most content
assessments: for quizzes, test, and other assessment content
maps: map files for learning modules
media: for images, videos, and other non-text content
resources: for example files or sources for screen shots.
The master map file, which references the map files for modules, is at the course-folder level.

Use the following file name prefixes:
m_ for map files
lc_ for learning content
lca_ for learning assessments

section.title: Standards for images
section.p: As a general rule, use web-friendly formats, such as PNG or GIF for images. Be sure that you have the rights to any images you include. Put images in the course-specific media folder and link them with a standard <image> element.

When the image is uploaded to WordPress, it is stored in a media subfolder with the current year and month, in the form yyyy/mm. Note the subfolder name, then add a base attribute to the <image> element, specifying the yyyy/mm subfolder name as the value.

conbody.section:
Standards for videos
The easiest way to provide videos is to post them on YouTube. Link to the video using a standard <xref> element. Remember to include the format attribute (html) and the scope attribute (external). Put the video link in its own paragraph and lead off with a “Video: ” label. <info>Video: <xref href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xGyf4q_Bipw" format="html" scope="external">Creating a menucascade in DITA</xref></info>For demo videos, begin your narration with the following information:
The purpose of the demo
The software you used
Software version
Operating system For example, you might say, “In this video, you’ll see how to create a task. I am using oXygen, version 17, running on a Mac.”
Keep your videos very short. One minute is good. Thirty seconds is better.
